clinical_study.brief_title: Effectiveness of a Telephone Intervention to Improve the Mental Health of Abused Women
clinical_study.official_title: A RCT to Test the Effectiveness of a Telephone Intervention to Improve the Mental Health of Community Dwelling Women Abused by Their Intimate Partners

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to determine if a telephone social support and empowerment intervention is more effective than usual community services in improving the mental health of community-dwelling women abused by their intimate partners.

detailed_description.textblock: Depression is one of the most common mental health sequelae of intimate partner violence (IPV). Although a range of interventions have been tried to improve the mental health of women survivors of IPV, the results are inconclusive. In this trial, a 12-week advocacy intervention consisting of empowerment and telephone social support is provided to abused Chinese women in a community setting. Usual community services provide the control condition.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Chinese women 18 years of age or older
- Self-report of psychological, physical or sexual abuse by their current or former intimate partner in the previous 12 months
- Live or work in a community within the catchment area of a community centre designated for the proposed study
Exclusion Criteria:
- Perpetrator is not an intimate partner
